awd_titl_txt: RESEARCH-PGR:  Living Fossils: Applying advances in single molecule sequencing to decode large and complex genomes of ancient plant lineages
awd_abstract_narration:
Darwin first used the term "living fossils" to describe a group of plants that had apparently survived intact for hundreds of millions of years.  During this time a wide range of environmental conditions occurred, including mass extinctions, and yet these plants survived. An intriguing question is how the living fossils were able to persist over millions of years and further, how their extant relatives diverged and evolved. Belonging to the cone-bearing, non-flowering group of plants, called gymnosperms, these species with huge and complex genomes could hold clues to understanding genomic resilience to environmental change. Advances in sequencing technologies are now available to answer these questions.  Very recently, approaches have become available to characterize these complex organisms genetically at a reasonable cost. This interdisciplinary team of researchers compare ancient and more highly evolved relatives to identify how genomes function, adapt and evolve. The project is dedicated to training the next generation of scientists and brings analytical and critical thinking skills to the general public through outreach activities. 
 
Three of the four extant gymnosperm lineages contain species which Darwin termed "living fossils." These have been present since the Devonian Era and have survived an incredible range of environmental conditions. The genomes of almost all the gymnosperms are extremely large and complex and have been somewhat refractive to genomic characterization as a result.  However, the development of the Oxford Nanopore PromethION sequencer, which can provide extremely long reads (greater than 10 kb) at a reasonable cost, will be used to carry out detailed characterization of the genomes of these plants as well as their more modern, radiated lineages. In addition, the methylation status of these species will be analyzed from multiple tissues to understand epigenomic variability. Specific questions about genome resilience and evolutionary relationships will be addressed. Advances in single molecule sequencing technologies from this project will have broad impact across the life sciences. Educational and outreach programs are designed to improve public understanding or science through engagement with the New York Botanical Garden, and project personnel will contribute expertise to developing exhibits at the American Museum of Natural History. All data and technology advances will be publicly available through public repositories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Living fossils are ancient species that have endured millions of years of climate change with minimal change to their outward appearance, or morphology. Gymnosperm, a broad class of plants, lineages include a mix of living fossils such as Wollemia nobilis (Wollemi Pine) and Metasequoia glyptostroboides along with more plants whose morphology have more recently changed, or radiated, such as Gnetum gnemon (Melinjo), Araucaria angustifolia (Parana Pine), and Juniperus communis (Common Juniper). Many of these exhibit distinctive traits shaped by their evolutionary histories and adaptations to their respective ecological niches. Due to this, they offer a unique opportunity to study the factors in their genomes that lead to their resiliency by comparing them to related species that have radiated to their current form more recently. Emerging as early as the Devonian period before the age of the dinosaurs, these species have survived environmental challenges, yet their genomes remain poorly understood due to their extraordinary size up to 20X larger than seed plants. Recent advances in long-read sequencing technologies now allow us to unravel the complexities of these genomes, providing an opportunity to investigate the evolutionary history, adaptation mechanisms, and genomic architecture of gymnosperm living fossils, especially as they relate to their more recently radiated related species. 


We produced a highly contiguous genome assembly of the endangered Wollemia nobilis and performed gene family analysis, small RNAs, and the genome methylation pattern (epigenome). We developed several new long-read sequencing methods and incorporated other genome technologies to bring the genome assemblies to the chromosomal level, making it one of the most complete genomes of its size (12 billion bases). We found a large proportion of transposons whose activity may contribute to epigenetic diversity and explored the regulatory interplay of small RNAs and methylation patterns. Our Australian collaborators provided genotype data sampled from the small remaining population, and our population genetics analyses indicate extremely low genetic diversity in the extant Wollemi pine population due to historical bottlenecks and clonal propagation. This population decline, estimated at the transition between the Miocene and Quaternary periods, is likely attributed to climate change and habitat fragmentation. Epigenetic studies, including small RNA and methylome sequencing, reveal ancient conservation of gene silencing mechanisms, while active transposons in reproductive tissues suggest a dynamic and adaptive genomic landscape. The initial version of the Wollemia manuscript was posted to BioRxiv in August 2023. 

 

We produced a chromosome-level assembly of Gnetum gnemon, a member of the Gnetales, and performed analyses of gene families, small RNAs, and the epigenome. The assembly was generated by combining nanopore sequencing and multiple other techniques resulting in 23 chromosome scale scaffolds. Gene family analysis reveals insights into traits such as branching, vasculature, and reproductive development. Transposable element (TE) activity, gene duplication events, and epigenetic features, such as methylation, contribute to understanding its unique genomic architecture. Analysis of TEs showed that Copia LTR retrotransposons are less abundant compared to several other plant genomes, while Gypsy LTR retrotransposons are highly ubiquitous. This finding may be an indicator of how Gnetum gnemon reacts to various stress stimuli. LTR retrotransposon expressions and integrations are inducible by climate stimuli. A Gnetum manuscript is in preparation that explores the unique morphological features of Gnetales such as their ability to exist as both trees and vines, and attempts to further classify their position in the evolution of land plants. This manuscript will be available on BioRxiv in 2025. 

 

We have completed long-read sequencing assemblies for the 3 other species. We are finalizing the Araucaria and Juniperus assemblies for public release and have made our Metasequoia data and draft assembly available.  We completed the sequencing of the transcriptome and methylation datasets for leaf and reproductive tissues for all genomes. Comparative genomic analyses of the living fossils to their speciated sister pairs that evolved more recently, (Wollemia to Araucaria, Juniperus to Metasequoia, and Gnetum to the previously published Welwitschia genome (Wan et al, Nature Communications 2021)) will be used to prepare a final manuscript available in early 2025 and will be highlighted at the Annual Plant and Animal Genomes conference in January 2025.

 

Studying the genomes of living fossil species is crucial for understanding the evolutionary history and genetic diversity of ancient lineages. These species represent some of the oldest surviving plant groups which retain unique traits that explain differences between extinct and modern plants. Insights from this study reveal mechanisms that drive their adaptations to environmental changes, such as shifts in climate and habitat. The study of these genomes enables the identification of conserved and novel gene families, TEs, and epigenetic mechanisms that contribute to their resilience and survival. This will have implications for conservation strategies, as many species face threats from habitat loss and climate change. Genomic data offer a foundation for preserving genetic diversity and developing informed management practices to ensure their survival in changing ecosystems.
